post.title: Trying out WebP images
post.body: After seeing them used on [hashtag_trashbag's](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HzKesHsWG3N96CfW9eC2aL9VKY7EDm2Zj) Blog i was intrigued by their small file size. Unfortunately they don't work natively on Firefox. I did a little research and found [webpjs](https://webpjs.appspot.com/), a script that converts webp images so they can be viewed on any browser. Using it is really easy: Just include the script in your index.html and it converts all webp images inside tags. Sadly this means they can't be used on ZeroBlogs, as the html is generated by a script when loading the page. So I just created a page by hand to try them: [PicDemo](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1PicDemof2Prf9G1QWAaDgyATFQnaqHhKa) Note that the page will freeze while converting the webp images, because the script is rather slow. Final thoughts: Though the small filesize is nice(all images on the page are 1,8M together), the lack of native support and the slow conversion using a script makes webp unpleasant to use. A Blog focused around posting images would be better of just using regular .jpg files. PS: I might write a program that automatically adds pictures to a Blog similar to the one shown here.

post.title: How To: custom ZeroNet addresses using Vanitygen
post.body: This Guide shows how to get custom ZeroNet addresses like this Site has ("3x71nc7" in the address). --- #Installation ###**Linux** First install git and all other dependencies: ```sudo apt-get install git libssl-dev libpcre3-dev ``` Now clone the Sourcecode from Github and compile it: ``` git clone https://github.com/samr7/vanitygen.git cd vanitygen make ``` ###**Windows** Download the Zip-file from here and extract it. That's all #Usage Open up a terminal/command-prompt and cd into the vanitygen directory. Then run ```./vanitygen 1YourAddress``` on Linux and ```vanitygen.exe 1YourAddress``` on Windows. The program will then try to find a address containing your specified part. Note that all addresses have to start with 1. Once vanitygen is done it will output a Address and a Privatekey. Make sure to save both. #Creating a ZeroNet site Open up your file explorer and navigate to ZeroNet's data directory. Once there create a new folder named after the address you got from vanitygen. To keep it simple we are just gonna copy another site for now. So go into the folder of another site and copy everything. Then go into the folder of your website and paste all the files in. Open content.json with a text editor and check that no domain it set. If it is, delete it. Shut down ZeroNet if you have it running and run the following command in the main directory of ZeroNet: **Linux** ```python zeronet.py siteSign yourAddress``` **Windows** Inside the ZeroNet folder execute this command: ```..\Python\python.exe zeronet.py siteSign yourAddress``` . On both Operating Systems you will be prompted to enter your Privatekey. By entering the Privatekey you "prove" that you are the owner of the Site by signing it. If somebody else gets your Privatekey they can then modify you page, so keep it secret. #Admiring what you did Start ZeroNet back up, open your Webbrowser and go to 127.0.0.1:43110/YourSitesAddress. If you cloned the ZeroBlog site you can now simply modify your Site using the Webinterface after dragging the 0 in the Top right to the left, scrolling down and switching the "This is my Site" switch. After modifying your site you can publish it by pressing the "Sign & Publish" button in the lower right. You will be asked for the Privatekey again. If you didn't clone the ZeroBlog site you have to manually sign it as explained in **Creating a ZeroNet site**. If you notice any mistakes or have any problems, feel free to comment.

post.title: I noticed a mistake
post.body:
After cloning the ZeroBlog page I didn't look in the content.json where the domain is set. 
So the link to my page on the Zeronet front-page is actually the .bit address of the ZeroBlog.

I have fixed it now, but to get my site displayed correctly on your front-page you have to delete it and visit it again.
Sorry for the inconvenience

post.title: A shoot 'em up game I made
post.body: It is written in Python 3 using Pygame for rendering. The Code is on Github. Run this on any Debian-based Linux Distro to install the dependencies: ```bash sudo apt-get install python3 mercurial hg clone https://bitbucket.org/pygame/pygame cd pygame sudo apt-get install python3-dev python3-numpy \ libsdl-dev libsdl-image1.2-dev \ libsdl-mixer1.2-dev libsdl-ttf2.0-dev \ libsmpeg-dev libportmidi-dev \ libavformat-dev libswscale-dev libjpeg-dev libfreetype6-dev python3 setup.py build sudo python3 setup.py install ``` Afterwards you can delete the pygame Folder. Now install git and get the code: ```bash sudo apt-get install git git clone https://github.com/TimseineLPs/SmupGame.git ``` Now cd into SmupGame and run ```python3 main.py``` to run the game ![image alt](img/smup.png) You move your ship with the arrow keys and shoot with the space bar. All the sprites are self-made using Piskel.
